text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

ADI IGNATIUS: Hi, everyone,
and welcome to HBR Quarantined.

I'm Adi Ignatius, editor in
chief of Harvard Business

Review, and I'm here with
my friend and colleague,

Josh Macht, who heads
product and innovation
at Harvard Business Publishing.

HBR Quarantined, this
is our fourth episode.

We decided to set
it up to connect

with the millions of
our fans and followers

who are working from home and
who are trying to figure out
how long is that going to last?

What is the world going
to look like as we
start to emerge from lockdown?

We're really pleased
with the response
that we've had to the show.

We know a lot of
people RSVPed for this.
That sounds very fancy.

I have to say we don't have
canapes or anything that

is sort of due to you,
but thank you for RSVPing.
Thank you for being here.

Our guest today, who I will
introduce formally in a second,

is Bozoma Saint John, who
is the CMO of Endeavor

and who is an expert
on how to kind of build

and rebuild and reinvent
your personality, your brand,

whether as an individual
or as a company.

And I think it's an important
thing for right now.

But before we
introduce her, I just

want to talk a little bit
about this phenomenon.

More and more companies
that have been closed
are talking about opening up.

The conversations I
have with colleagues

continue to go along
the lines of people

saying they're dying to
get back in the office.

And when I say,
yeah, but you may

be wearing a mask in
the office, people say,

I'm dying not to get
back in the office.
So it's complicated.

I don't know, Josh, what
are you thinking these days?
JOSHUA MACHT: I don't know.
It's interesting.

I think we're all having
some fatigue here for sure.
There's no question.
You know, I--

ADI IGNATIUS: I'm
having ennui, I think.
JOSHUA MACHT: Ennui, right.

I'm not sure exactly
what that means,
but you'll tell me later.
You're good with that.

But I just feel like
doing simple things,

like I went to get a piece
of pizza, a slice of pizza

at a place and felt pretty
good about it, but also

at the same time a
little uncomfortable.

There were people
congregating, and I didn't
want to be anywhere near that.

And you just start to
realize as we get out,

you've got this impulse
of, I want to get back out.

But at the same time,
you want to be safe.
You want to be vigilant.

You don't want to
let your guard down.
It's really weird.

It's a weird feeling,
don't you think?
ADI IGNATIUS: I do.

I mean, I'm wondering
more and more what
is the purpose of an office?

I used to think the
purpose of an office was

it was a place that you
could leave to get home.

Now I'm starting to think
it's actually a place that you
want to leave home for.

I mean, I do miss the
casual interaction,
the sort of mentoring.

You didn't really
think about it.
I miss the commute.

I think I said that last week,
those transition moments that

tell you it's not
just Groundhog Day,

that we're going from
one reality to another.
They're helpful moments.
JOSHUA MACHT: No, I know.

I mean, The New York
Times has a piece that--

we all make fun of the office,
but yet there's a camaraderie

and there's something
that comes with it.

I miss those moments
right after the meeting.

And I know that from Veep they
have those funny segments of,

did I miss the meeting about
the meeting and all those jokes.

But there are little
moments where you huddle,
where you meet with people.
You walk down the hall.
You make sense of things.

And in this new reality,
it's just like a thud.
You stop the meeting.

You're kind of by
yourself like, OK.
Click on the next meeting.
And therein is the fatigue.
Therein is the monotony.

But again, what are
you willing to risk
to get back to the office?
ADI IGNATIUS: Yeah.

Well, I think more and more
people are willing to risk.

There's an understanding
that we can't be risk free.
Look, I mean, there was--
I don't know if you saw it.

The stock market
shot up this morning

because a Boston
company, Moderna,
said it had positive early--

it's phase 1, a small number
of people, but pretty good

early results in
the vaccine trial.

It adds up to
nothing necessarily,
but we'll get there eventually.

But there's going to be
a long time before then

where we're going to
have to accept risk
as part of our lives.
JOSHUA MACHT: Yeah, absolutely.

Those things are a
little doses of hope.

Sorry if you hear lawnmowers
in the background here.

ADI IGNATIUS: No, that's
the reality nowadays.

OK, so before I
reintroduce Bozoma,

I want to just say
a quick note how you
can support HBR and the show.

If you'd like the show, if you
like the coverage that we've

been doing on COVID-19
and its fallout,

be sure to check out
HBR.org for more content,
and consider subscribing.

You could find all
the details there.

This of course would be a
great opportunity for a sponsor
to put in a message.

So, Josh, I don't know if
you have a fake [INAUDIBLE]..

JOSHUA MACHT: No, that was
our slot for an advertiser,

so we just talked
about ourselves.
Go to HBR.org.
Subscribe.

But if you want,
you can advertise,

and then we wouldn't have
to do this right now.
You could be in this spot.

ADI IGNATIUS: All right, so
before we go to Bozoma Saint

John, who, as I said, is
an expert on reinvention,

our TikTok team created a video
that we think coincidentally is
sort of relevant to the theme.

So engineer Dave, if you
can roll that TikTok.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Just no questions.
It's TikTok.

It's my pleasure now to
introduce the amazing Bozoma
Saint John.

As I said, she's CMO of
Endeavor and an expert

on how to build and reinvent
your brand and your purpose.

She was formerly chief
brand officer at Uber.

She was head of global consumer
marketing at Apple Music

and iTunes, head of music
and entertainment at PepsiCo.

She has an amazing
Instagram feed,

and you're seeing some of
that in the background.

BuzzFeed once called
her the coolest person

to ever go onstage at an Apple
event, which is a low bar,

but still, Bozoma, we're
really glad to have you here.

BOZOMA SAINT JOHN: Thank
you so much, Adi and Josh.
That's hysterical.

It is quite a low bar,
but you know what?
I wear that mantle proudly.

I would put it on my
bio, but it didn't fit,

so I'll consider how
to shorten it later.

ADI IGNATIUS: We're
happy to be your show.

So I want to ask you,
where are you now?

And how-- we've been working
from home for 10 weeks.

What has your life
been like these last 10
weeks working from home?
BOZOMA SAINT JOHN: Yeah.

I read a quote recently
that just hit home for me.

It was about the fact that we
are not all in the same boat,

but we are all in
the same storm.

So while I may have
different circumstances,

or while we might all have
different circumstances,

we're all sort of facing the
same challenges, same issues,

same anxieties, same
fear, all those things.
So, yeah, where I am.

Physically I'm in
LA in my home, where

I am quarantined with my
daughter, who is almost 11
in two weeks, and my mother.

And it is the first time I
have lived with my mother
since I was 18 years old.

And to have the
three generations
here in the same house--
woo!
It's been quite a learning.

And emotionally where I am and
I guess psychologically has
changed a bit over 10 weeks.

It vacillates between
feeling very motivated,

and feeling like
this is the time

to do anything and everything,
to feelings of despair.

Feeling like, gosh, well, things
will never be the same again.

What in the hell am
I doing right now,
and what's the point?
And everything else in between.

So, yeah, quite a
philosophical where are you.

JOSHUA MACHT: How do you deal
with the sinking moments?

I mean, that's what
I find is a little--

what do you-- because you're
really quite an inspiration.

And I follow you on
Instagram and everything.

And I wonder, how do
you pick yourself up?
BOZOMA SAINT JOHN: Yeah.

Well you know, Josh,
this is the thing,

is that because none of us have
ever dealt with this before,

I am also learning
how to motivate myself

and that some of my
old tricks don't work.

I used to have a pretty
dynamic schedule,

meaning that I was on
the move constantly.

So there was no time to
sort of wallow and wonder,

well, how am I going to
get x, y, and z thing done.
You know what they say.

It's like, if you
want something done,
give it to the busiest person.
And that's what my life was.
It was just a constant movement.

And so therefore if I needed
to get something done,

I would just figure out how to
get it done in the schedule,

and I wouldn't even
worry about it.
It would just be, get it done.

And these days because
it feels like time

is infinite, it feels like,
oh, I have so many hours,

that I find it
difficult to get even
some of the small things done.

You know the projects that
maybe you had at the house

that you wanted to get
done and you're like, oh,

now I'm going to
build that bookcase.
But guess what?

The pieces are still
sitting over there.
I still haven't touched it.

And so I'm finding that I've
had to redo my schedule.

And to me, that is actually what
gives me motivation, the times
to actually get things done.

And if I can live by that, I
find that I'm more productive.

So it means that I am waking
up at a particular time
of the day.
I am working out.

I am then going
into my meetings.
I have my time to eat.

I have my time to get
up and move around.

I have a time to sit
back down to a meeting.
I have a time to have lunch.
I have my times set.

That way it is
much easier for me

to stay sort of
moving and going,

versus just endless hours that
seem to run into each other.

ADI IGNATIUS: So before
I ask the next question,

I want to encourage
all our viewers,

please ask your own
questions of Bozoma.

Put them into the
comment box, and we'll

try to get to some
of those later.

Bozoma, the phrase that's always
associated with your name--

I think it's the moniker
you picked yourself--
is badass, Bozoma Badass.

You've been talking about a
show called Bozoma Being Badass.
I want to be badass.

Give me some advice on how
to be badass like Bozoma.
JOSHUA MACHT: You are, man.
You are.

ADI IGNATIUS: Oh,
that's very kind.
I want to be more badass.

JOSHUA MACHT: But
like in a weird way.

But OK, let's hear
from the expert.

BOZOMA SAINT JOHN:
I think you have
a badass environment right now.

What I can see, I
like the badass design

that you've got going
on in your environment.
So I'm thinking--

ADI IGNATIUS: This is
18th century badass.

BOZOMA SAINT JOHN:
I mean, pretty dope.
Pretty, pretty dope.

But you know what's so funny is
that I when I picked badass--

yes, self-described--
I didn't do it

because I thought that it
would turn into something that
would sort of follow me around.
It was kind of just a good time.

I just felt like everything
that I was doing was on a level
that I felt like a superhero.

And superheroes to
me are badasses.

They're the ones who
aren't afraid to go in

to meet the bad guy, or run
into the burning building,
or save the planet.

And sometimes it felt like
that's what I was doing.

And I definitely had
the vision in my mind

that it looked
like the comic book

strip, where it says badass
written with the lightning
bolt.

And that's what it
feels like to me.

So you can be badass in just
being exactly who you are.

I think that's actually
the funniest thing

is that we think
that it means taking

on the mantle of
something much bigger.
But I used to say--

I used to have in
my social media bios

that there's nothing more
badass than being yourself.

And it is probably the
hardest thing to do,

and perhaps sometimes the
most frightening thing
is being 100% yourself.

ADI IGNATIUS: Let me just
follow up quickly on that,

because I sort of sum
up your philosophy,

what I can glean from your
social media presence,

as sort of do your own thing
and be true to yourself.

And at a certain level,
that seems tougher now when

to cope with a pandemic,
we're thinking more

about the general good,
about tamping down

our own selfish
desires, I guess.

So I guess how do you reconcile
the ego versus collective pull
at the moment?
BOZOMA SAINT JOHN: Wow.

That is a really,
really tough question.
Because I really do believe--

ADI IGNATIUS: It's
a badass question.

BOZOMA SAINT JOHN:
[LAUGH] That it is.
It is a badass question.

Because I believe so firmly and
so wholly in the power of one.

It is part of the reason why
I say bring your whole self.

I don't say bring
the whole community.
It's bring your whole self.

Because we have
such a problem, I

think a real problem in
our collective society

with bringing ourselves, with
actually living our truest
self.

And until we do
that, we actually

can't influence and do anything
about the greater good.
We can't serve the greater good.

In fact, at this
particular time,

it's the most important
time to make sure
that we are focused on self.

Maybe that's contrary
to popular belief.

But if you are not well,
if you aren't at your best,

if you're not coping with the
things that are causing you

either anxiety or depression
or any of the other ills,

then how can you be
good for your family
or good for your community?
You can't.
It's almost impossible.

And so right now, while
it might feel selfish,

it's actually really
important that we sit and work

on what is in here before
we consider doing something
for the greater good.

Of course, all of us want
to be the hero, right?

Champion for the society
and do something great

for those who are serving
or any of the other things,

which, by the way,
all wonderful things.

But I implore you not to do it,
not to do any of those things

unless you feel whole
within yourself.

Because otherwise
we'll have a disaster

on our hands with a lot
of halfway well people

who are trying to
do something good

and then end up actually
crashing the entire society.

JOSHUA MACHT: No, that's
a really good point.

And it also gets at the notion
of bringing your authentic self
to work.
And I like what you're saying.
Be your whole true self.
Bring that out.
Bring that out to the world.
That's a big message for you.

At the same time,
you're also someone

who's gone through
reinvention, and you
work with people who have.

Can you help us to square
the two of reinvention
with being true to yourself?

How do you [INAUDIBLE]
those two together?

BOZOMA SAINT JOHN:
You know what?

Y'all some badass
interviewers, OK?

Let's just say that because
these questions are like,
pow pow!
It's so good.
Wow.

ADI IGNATIUS: You're
a badass flatterer.

JOSHUA MACHT: Which
totally works.
ADI IGNATIUS: It works on me.

BOZOMA SAINT JOHN:
Good, good, good.
Let's keep going.

It's such a-- gosh, that's
such a deep question about how

to square up the true
and authentic self
with reinvention.

But really the connective
tissue between the two

is about evolution, an
allowing of evolution.
We should evolve.
We should get better.
We should change.
I think that's actually when--
I was looking through my--

I was supposed to be going to
my 25th high school reunion

this year, and I was looking
through my high school
yearbook.

And people write the messages
like never change and all that,

which is ridiculous
because we should always
be in a state of change.

And so the idea of
bringing your full self

or your whole authentic self
is even within that evolution.

And so not pretending to
be somewhere where you

aren't or be someone
who you aren't.

If you've not evolved into
that higher your being that you
aspire to, it is OK.
We're all on the journey.

But it's OK then to
reach a certain marker

and be that person, and
then evolve some more
and be that next person.

Just always being
conscious of presenting

whatever state it is that
you're in fully and wholly
and not pretending.
I think that's just it.

It's the lack of pretense to me
that I am trying to shake off,
that mask that we put on.

Whether it's in the
office, or with a friend,

or at church, or at
your daughter's school,

or wherever else, it's like
we wear this mask all the time

to present something that
is actually not true.

When if we didn't
do that, we actually
find more empathy in the world.

We'd be able to connect
better with each other

because we would realize
that, well, sometimes we

are all truly more of the
same than we are different,
although that sounds so corny.

But also I think that we
would find that we have
so many shared experiences.

And it's something
I learned when

I was like 12, to
not put that mask on

and to be able to
share what I am

and who I am quite
freely without apology.

And it worked then, so why in
the hell would I change it now?
ADI IGNATIUS: So far so good.

I'm going to go to a question
from one of our viewers.
So this is Tahir from Dubai.

And this is really a question
relevant to this moment, which

is, how do you build your brand
while we're all being held back
during this crisis?
How do you get the message out?

How do you build a brand in this
kind of clutter of pandemic?

BOZOMA SAINT JOHN: That's
also a really good question
because right now--

look, I said it
at the beginning,
is a great time to go inward.

That reevaluating who you
are, what you stand for,

what your values are, what
you want in the future,

what you want right now,
what is the journey that you
want to be on is so important.

I find that many
people miss that step.

They go directly to
how do I create a brand

and forget it if
you don't know what

the brand is, there's no way
to actually communicate it.

So really understanding who you
are and what you stand for that

is unique and different
from everybody else.

And that requires, like I
said, the true identity, really

going in and understanding
who it is that you are.

And by the way, have you been
presenting someone different
in the world?

Have you been presenting a
masked version of yourself?

Well, I guess these
things masks are in vogue.

But are you presenting someone
or something that is not true?

And if that is the
case, spend the time

now going in and making
sure that you actually
understand who you are.

You can't be all things to
all people, so who is it?
What purpose do you serve?

What are your
likes and dislikes?
What are your value systems?

And it can't be that
hoity-toity thing.
It can't be that.
Disregard that thing.
Yes, you want to save the world.
OK, that's fantastic.
We all do.
But that's too broad.

We need to get down
to the smaller things,

and then begin to
actually behave that way.

And behavior is not just
what you're walking around
with in the world.

Behavior is not because
you went to a certain event
or you spoke at a conference.

Behavior is in the
conversations you have
with your family and friends.

Behavior is how you present
yourself on Instagram
or LinkedIn or Facebook.

Behavior is in the
act, and then you

take on, and perhaps the
plan that you create for when
you can move in the world.

So to me, the brand building
are the deep questions

that I ask of not just inanimate
brands, but of people brands
too.
So first it's like, who are you?
Really, who are you?
What do you stand for?
What are your value systems?
What do you not like?
Who do you not like?
[LAUGHTER]

ADI IGNATIUS:
That's a long list.

BOZOMA SAINT JOHN:
All of those answers

are really important
to narrowing

down and understanding
your own self.
ADI IGNATIUS: Can I do--

Josh, if I can interrupt
just to do a quick follow-up.
JOSHUA MACHT: Sure.

ADI IGNATIUS: So
this is a question

from Paul from Kirkcaldy, United
Kingdom, that built on that.

So if you're looking
to change career paths,

would you advise one to
wait for the new normal

to sort of establish
itself and even out,

or would you advise to
kind of forge a path now

before we even know what the
new normal is going to be?

BOZOMA SAINT JOHN:
Oh, that's a good one.

ADI IGNATIUS: Thank you,
Paul from Kirkcaldy.

BOZOMA SAINT JOHN: Yeah,
I like that question.

Because another one of my
monikers is to live urgently.

I am not patient,
and I am not a person
who tells other people to wait.
And so, Paul, don't wait.
Do it right now.

Because the truth
of the matter is

that it's kind of like the
advice I was giving about brand

development and understanding
self, which is that if you want

to change careers, are you
doing any work in the career
that you want to go into?

Are there ways for
you to dip your toe
in the water of the new career?

Are there ways to start
to do that work right now

in the safety of our
slowed world, where

there are no real pressures
before you jump in fully?

If there are questions,
if you have questions

about moving in
that direction, I

would begin with
the small steps.

Like we were
saying, right now it

feels like there's
infinite time.

But are there really
two hours in the day

when you're not doing
your current job

or your current career to
dedicate to the new one,
in order to the new job?

If you don't have the new job
and you haven't secured it yet

and this is a question about
actually leaving your job

to go to the next one,
perhaps financially you're

not able to do that, or maybe
the jobs aren't open yet.

But are there ways to get
informationals and even
volunteer your time?

I know that sounds
kind of crazy.

But I don't know that there
are very many companies who

would turn down volunteer
employees right now.

And so if you have
a few hours and you

want to get your path
into that new career

and you don't want to
leave your current job,

yes, of course, do
the work of your job.

Please keep your current job if
you can't leave it right now.

But absolutely find
ways to insert yourself

into the new industry or the new
company that you want to be in.

They will take volunteer
employees, for sure.
ADI IGNATIUS: We ran a piece--

actually the most read
piece on HBR yesterday

was something we brought
back by Peter Bregman

that we published a few
years ago called "Practice
Being your Future Self."

And his argument was you
have to let the present just
sit there untended.

Meaning don't do
the drudge work.
Don't answer all those emails.

Don't think, I'm going
to finish all my work,

and then I'm going to think
about recreating myself

into the person I
really want to be.

That you just have
to be, as he said,

irresponsible with the current
challenges to really make

progress to figure
out the future you.

BOZOMA SAINT JOHN:
Yes, yes, I do

agree with that in that it
is time to take some risk.

Now of course measured
risk, as I said.

It's like there
are ways right now,

the luxury we have right now
that we didn't have before,

which is in
straddling two worlds.

That, yes, we all have time
to dedicate-- like I said,

if you have a job now or
you're in a career now,

we have time to dedicate
towards that job,

and it's not 12 hours
a day for most of us.

Even if it's eight
hours a day, and as you

were saying in your
intro, you sort of miss

the casual movement, casual
interactions, the commute

and all those things, that's
time back that we have.

And so can you schedule
within your day time,

then, to dedicate towards the
new career or the new idea,

that future self
that you want to be?
And I think that it's perfect.

Like I said, I think any
company at this point

would be more than
happy to have employees
who volunteer their time.

JOSHUA MACHT: So can
we shift for a second

to your industry of
sports and entertainment?
Because it feels like--

I mean, talk about
reinvention or at least

finding its way without
people wanting to congregate.
That's such a big part of that.

I know personally I'm sort
of yearning for any sports
to come back.

I'm watching The Last Dance as
if these basketball games were
happening now because I just--
BOZOMA SAINT JOHN: Oh, I know.
JOSHUA MACHT: Yeah, right?
I just crave it.
ADI IGNATIUS: It's all we got.
JOSHUA MACHT: It's well-timed.

It's incredibly well
done, fun to watch.

But people aren't going to
feel comfortable congregating.

What's that going to mean
for sports and entertainment
going forward?
BOZOMA SAINT JOHN: Yeah.

Well, I think like all things,
it will make its way back,
just in a different way.

I don't believe that our
congregating masses are over
forever.

That we will find a way
to get back together.

So we have to figure out
right now how to manage
that, of course safely.

And that's what
every entertainment

platform is trying to do,
especially live entertainment.
It's like, how do you do that?
Can we gather people safely?

Are there innovative
ways to do that?

And I've said it a million times
to my team over the last 10

weeks that this is probably
the greatest marketing
test of all time.
That if we have to innovate--

and by the way, it's not just
innovate and sort of test it,
but innovate and go.

Like it's innovation
and live immediately.
There is no test.

And so we're going to either
really win or really fail.
There's almost no great.

And so I think that at
this very moment in time,

because of the desire
of our audiences

to get back together safely,
or to just be in the moment,
we have to figure that out.

That's our responsibility now,
to innovate in that space.
And you're right.
